```
after 100 iterations memory (MB) | allocated: 1203.412109375 | max allocated: 15407.95068359375 | cached: 15762.0 | max cached: 15762.0
time (ms) | forward: 43.53 | backward: 42.59 | allreduce: 0.00 | optimizer: 0.01 | batch generator: 1.11 | data loader: 0.78
```

ORT reduce 23.14% latency of single training pass. 30.00% reduction in forward pass, 15.29% reduction in backward pass.

```

Iteration      100/     100 | elapsed time per iteration (ms): 192.8 | learning rate 0.000E+00 | lm loss 4.414931E+00 | loss scale 2097152.0 |
after 100 iterations memory (MB) | allocated: 2539.90234375 | max allocated: 27185.822265625 | cached: 29410.0 | max cached: 29410.0

after 100 iterations memory (MB) | allocated: 1865.3564453125 | max allocated: 27692.6025390625 | cached: 28394.0 | max cached: 28394.0
time (ms) | forward: 64.30 | backward: 62.76 | allreduce: 0.00 | optimizer: 0.02 | batch generator: 1.03 | data loader: 0.70
```

title: Decouple Forward and Backward of ATenOp
body:
Decouple forward and backward for ATenOp, so the ATenOp forward (for inference or node doesn't require grad) can run. The PR includes:
- Remove attribute for ATenOp, all arguments will be inputs of ATenOp node, those non-tensor arguments will be CPU inputs.
- Use op_name and overload_name to determin the ATen operator.
- Remove ATenOp config for ATenOp forward run. All inputs will be converted to DLPacks, torch extension will convert these DLPacks to ATen operator arugments according to the operator schema and run.
- Remove ATenOpGrad. Use ATenOp node for both forward and backward.
- Move ATenOp's gradient definition to frontend. Use Python code to define ATenOp's gradient, we can use multiple ONNX Ops and ATenOp nodes to define a single ATenOp's gradient. The definition will be passed to backend in JSON format when backend build the gradient graph for ATenOp nodes.
- Move PyTorch exporter overriding function to the same place as the ATenOp gradient definitions, and also use Python decorator to register them.
- Add support to torch.argmax for forward run only, which is required by one of the models we are investigating on for now. ORT currently doesn't have CUDA kernel for ArgMax for OpSet12 or larger, because we are using CUDNN for the implementation for ArgMax, but CUDNN cannot support the new attribute "select_last_index" added since OpSet 12.

Moving forward:
- This change can support inference for those graph contains ATenOp node generated by exporter. Currently all codes are under ENABLE_TRAINING, in the future to enable running for inference, we need to move ATenOp schema and kernel from orttraining folder to onnxruntime folder.

title: GPU memory consumption drastically increased in onnxruntime-gpu==1.8.0
body:
**Describe the bug**
Evaluating an ONNX model consumed 130 MB of GPU memory in 1.7.0, while with 1.8.0 it takes 3.2 GB of GPU memory.

**Urgency**
Blocks the upgrade to 1.8.0.

**System information**
- OS Platform and Distribution: Windows
- ONNX Runtime installed from: onnxruntime-gpu Python package
- ONNX Runtime version: 1.8.0
- Python version: 3.6
- CUDA/cuDNN version: 11.2/8.x
- GPU model and memory: GeForce GTX 1070, 8 GB

**To Reproduce**
```
import numpy as np
import onnxruntime
import pynvml

pynvml.nvmlInit()
device_handle = pynvml.nvmlDeviceGetHandleByIndex(0)

def get_used_gpu_mem():
    return pynvml.nvmlDeviceGetMemoryInfo(device_handle).used

dnn_path = "model.onnx"
onnx_session = onnxruntime.InferenceSession(dnn_path)

input_name = onnx_session.get_inputs()[0].name
input_shape = onnx_session.get_inputs()[0].shape
input_img = np.random.rand(1, 3, 256, 256).astype(np.float32)

mem_before = get_used_gpu_mem()
onnx_session.run(None, {input_name: input_img})[0][0]
mem_after = get_used_gpu_mem()
print("before:   {:>15,}".format(mem_before))
print("after:    {:>15,}".format(mem_after))
print("increase: {:>15,}".format(mem_after - mem_before))
```

**with onnxruntime-gpu==1.7.0**:
```
before:     1,069,457,408
after:      1,199,480,832
increase:     130,023,424
```
**with onnxruntime-gpu==1.8.0**:
```
before:     1,071,685,632
after:      4,351,631,360
increase:   3,279,945,728
```

title: Enable BN Training Mode in CPU Inference Build
body:
Enable training mode for BatchNorm CPU kernel in inference build. This is required by some exporter unit tests that compare pytorch vs ONNX model outputs to verify the exported model. These tests run as part of the pytorch CI, and we have a CPU environment set up there.

We have the agreement that training specific ops should not be included in inf builds, Ops used for both training and inf paths but have special training logic may be included in inf builds. Here training specific ops are referring to Gradient ops, Optimizer ops, Communication ops that will never be used in the inference mode. Onnx Ops with training mode logic can be include in the inference build.

title: Linux CUDA performance with the C++ API
body:
I am trying using the C++ API using the provided sample that runs the SqueezeNet model (https://github.com/microsoft/onnxruntime/blob/master/csharp/test/Microsoft.ML.OnnxRuntime.EndToEndTests.Capi/C_Api_Sample.cpp), and I am trying to evaulate the latency when using the CUDA provider.

I have already tried with two GPUs (a GTX 1060 and a P100) and two ONNX runtime versions with their supported CUDA versions (ONNX v1.6 with CUDA 10.2, and ONNX v1.8 with CUDA 11) on two different machines (Ubuntu 18.04 and 20.04) and in each case, the performance was significantly worse compared to the CPU provider.

title: reformat build suffix so that the latest is always correct
body:
**Description**:         
# we want to format the build_suffix to avoid (the 12th run on 20210630 vs the first run on 20210701):
        # 2021063012 > 20210701
        # in above 2021063012 is treated as the latest which is incorrect.
        # we want to convert the format to:
        # 20210630012 < 20210701001
        # where the first 8 digits are date. the last 3 digits are run count.
        # as long as there are less than 1000 runs per day, we will not have the problem.

title: Refactor QDQ optimizers to enable future usage in minimal build
body:
### Changes
- Add new SelectorActionTransformer that splits node selection from node modification to allow just the modifications to be applied at runtime in a minimal build. 
  - This is the first step of a few to enable a QDQ model to be optimized at runtime in mobile scenarios. Initial changes involve replacing the existing QDQ optimizers and adding the transformer infrastructure. Next changes will enable usage in a minimal build/ORT format model, as well as adding NNAPI specific QDQ handling.
- Add generic and QDQ specific helpers for selection (Selectors) and modification (Actions). The modification must maintain the graph edges in a valid state as Graph::Resolve isn't available in a minimal build to fix any issues with edges.
- Replace existing QDQ optimizers with optimizer based on new approach.

### Structure
- Selector instances run the checks to determine if a set of nodes can be modified by the optimization. This set of nodes is represented by a NodesToOptimize instance, which has entries for the target node, the input nodes and output nodes. 
- Action instances apply the modification to this set of nodes. 
- NodesToOptimize can be serialized as NodeIndex values so that in a minimal build we can re-create the NodesToOptimize instance (if all nodes are still valid) and call the associated Action. 
  - This minimizes binary size as we don't need any of the selection logic, and most actions can be implemented using generic code to move edges and replace a node (optimizations are generally the fusion/replacement of one or more nodes, with the input/output edges moving to the new node). 
- A general purpose SelectorActionTransformer is provided with which Selector+Action pairs are registered using the operators and opsets that these should be run for. 
  - Note that a separate SelectorActionTransformer should be created/registered for each related set of optimizations, so usage is based on that group of related things being available and registered in one place. 
  - It is expected that we'll convert more higher level optimizations to this approach so that a general purpose ORT format model can be optimized in different ways (e.g. run the QDQ as well as NHWC optimizations) at runtime based on the current device capabilities. 

### Motivation and Context
Improve flexibility and performance of mobile models.

body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
I want to use ONNXRuntime on my node app. However, this app needs to be compatible with Linux on x64 and arm64.
This is an issue, since there's no prebuilt binary for arm64.
I would build my own binary, but it's unpractical for many reasons, one of them being electron-forge doesn't allow npm dependencies on local files.

I would like the ONNX releases to include a binary for Linux-arm64 like: `onnxruntime-linux-arm64-1.8.0.tgz`

**Describe alternatives you've considered**
A clear and concise description of any alternative solutions or features you've considered.
The alternative would be for me to create my own npm bindings for ONNX Runtime with the same `prebuild-install` script as yours, but including the binary that I need from a repository of my own. This is not ideal, since I would have to manage my own builds/releases.

Another alternative would be to fallback to source compile if no binaries were found.

title: Inference result different between cpu and gpu onnxruntime
body:
**Describe the bug**
On model deployment, we found the inference result different between cpu and gpu onnxruntime library while the model is same.

**System information**
- Linux Debian
- ONNX Runtime installed from (source or binary):  Python version: onnxruntime-gpu==1.5.1
- CUDA/cuDNN version: cuda 10.2
- GPU model and memory: Tesla T4

**To Reproduce**
- Describe steps/code to reproduce the behavior.
- Attach the ONNX model to the issue (where applicable) to expedite investigation.
- Here is the example code to reproduce the bug.
```python
import sys
import struct

import numpy as np
import onnxruntime as ort

DATA_ROOT = './'
model_file = DATA_ROOT + '/fair_seq_encoder_k_v.onnx'

inputs = DATA_ROOT + "/fairseq_encoder_input.bin"

cpu_output_path = DATA_ROOT + "/fairseq_encoder_output_cpu.bin";

with open(inputs, 'rb') as f:
  data = f.read()
fmt = 'f' * (515 * 80)
inputs = struct.unpack(fmt, data)
inputs = np.array(inputs, dtype=np.float32).reshape((1, 515, 80))

with open(cpu_output_path, 'rb') as f:
  data = f.read()
fmt = 'f' * (10*4*128*192)
cpu_output = struct.unpack(fmt, data)
cpu_output = np.array(cpu_output, dtype=np.float32).reshape((-1))

ort_session = ort.InferenceSession(model_file)

gpu_output = ort_session.run(None, {'encoder_feats': inputs,
                       'encoder_feats_lengths': np.array([515]),
                       'beam_size': np.array([10])})

gpu_output = gpu_output[0].reshape((-1))

print(f'maximum difference between onnxruntime cpu & gpu'
      f' is {np.max(np.abs(gpu_output - cpu_output)):.4f}')
```

**Expected behavior**
Theoretically the difference between gpu and cpu is expected to be a very small number, like `1e-7`.

**Screenshots**
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/43900898/123573956-8e5da200-d801-11eb-9ad0-4297f62c600e.png)

**Additional context**
[Here is the onnx model and test code](https://drive.google.com/file/d/17Sizt2q80Kt-If6dkFGS6SXnXuZpP67N/view?usp=sharing)

title: Quantized model does not support dynamic axes

labels.name: feature:quantization
labels.description: related to quantization of models or running quantized models

body:
**Describe the bug**
Onnx model converted from pytorch supports dynamic axes. where as the quantized onnx model does not support dynamic axes

**System information**
- OS Platform and Distribution (e.g., Linux Ubuntu 16.04): Linux Ubuntu 16.04
- ONNX Runtime installed from (source or binary): source
- ONNX Runtime version: 1.8.0
- Python version: 3.6.9
- Visual Studio version (if applicable):
- GCC/Compiler version (if compiling from source):
- CUDA/cuDNN version: no
- GPU model and memory: no

**To Reproduce**
```
import os
os.environ["CUDA_VISIBLE_DEVICES"]="-1"
os.environ["OMP_NUM_THREADS"]="5"

import numpy as np
import onnxruntime
import torch
from transformers import (
    AutoTokenizer,
    AutoConfig,
    AutoModelForSequenceClassification
)

from onnxruntime.quantization import quantize_qat, QuantType



# load the model and tokenizer
tokenizer = AutoTokenizer.from_pretrained('xlm-roberta-base')
model = AutoModelForSequenceClassification.from_pretrained('xlm-roberta-base')
device = torch.device("cpu")
model.eval()
model.to(device)



# sample texts with max length = 35
# this will create a sample input of 6x35
max_seq_length = 35
sample_texts = ['the impact of the Delta plus strain will become clear only as more cases are identified',
                'the impact of the Delta plus strain will become clear only as more cases are identified',
                'The BBC said the documents suggested the ships mission was conducted in the expectation that Russia might respond aggressively.',
                'You should probably TRAIN this model on a down-stream task to be able to use it for predictions and inference.',
                'Some of these countries are slated to open their borders in July, and in some direct flights are not yet operational.',
                'So do check the dates and details before firming up any travel plans.']
tokenized_ouputs = tokenizer.batch_encode_plus(
            sample_texts,
            max_length=max_seq_length,
            padding="max_length",
            return_tensors='pt',
            truncation=True,
            return_attention_mask=True,
            add_special_tokens=True
        )



# conver the model to onnx model using the sample text as input
with torch.no_grad():
    symbolic_names = {0: 'batch_size', 1:'max_seq_len'}
    torch.onnx.export(model,
                      args=tuple(tokenized_ouputs.values()),
                      f='xlmronnx_model.onnx',
                      opset_version=11,
                      do_constant_folding=False,
                      input_names=['input_ids', 'attention_mask'],
                      output_names=['logits'],
                      dynamic_axes={'input_ids': symbolic_names, 'attention_mask': symbolic_names})
                                        
# created a session for the onnx model to test
session = onnxruntime.InferenceSession('xlmronnx_model.onnx', providers=['CPUExecutionProvider'])



# test 1: text of length 35
test1 = tokenizer.batch_encode_plus(
            ["A text can be any example of written or spoken language"],
            max_length=35,
            padding='max_length',
            return_tensors=None,
            truncation=True,
            return_attention_mask=True,
            add_special_tokens=True
        )
input_dict_np1 = {'input_ids':np.array(test1['input_ids']), 'attention_mask':np.array(test1['attention_mask'])}

# test 2: same text in test1, but of length 45
test2 = tokenizer.batch_encode_plus(
            ["A text can be any example of written or spoken language", "Five dead in mexico in hot air ballon crash"],
            max_length=45,
            padding='max_length',
            return_tensors=None,
            truncation=True,
            return_attention_mask=True,
            add_special_tokens=True
        )
input_dict_np2 = {'input_ids':np.array(test2['input_ids']), 'attention_mask':np.array(test2['attention_mask'])}

# test 3: same text in test1, but of length 45 with truncation
test3 = tokenizer.batch_encode_plus(
            ["A text can be any example of written or spoken language"],
            max_length=45,
            padding=False,
            return_tensors=None,
            truncation=True,
            return_attention_mask=True,
            add_special_tokens=True
        )
input_dict_np3 = {'input_ids':np.array(test3['input_ids']), 'attention_mask':np.array(test3['attention_mask'])}



# print output of test1
print(session.run(None, input_dict_np1)[0])

# print output of test2
print(session.run(None, input_dict_np2)[0])

# print output of test3
print(session.run(None, input_dict_np3)[0])



# quantize the above model
quantized_model = quantize_qat('xlmronnx_model.onnx', 'xlmronnx_model_quantized.onnx')
quantized_session = onnxruntime.InferenceSession('xlmronnx_model_quantized.onnx', providers=['CPUExecutionProvider'])



# print output of test1 for quantized model
print(quantized_session.run(None, input_dict_np1)[0])

# print output of test2 for quantized model
print(quantized_session.run(None, input_dict_np2)[0])

# print output of test2 for quantized model
print(quantized_session.run(None, input_dict_np3)[0])
```

title: onnxruntime gpu performance 5x worse than pytorch gpu performance
body:
**Goal**
The end goal is to speed up the segmentation model from [segmentation_models.pytorch](https://github.com/qubvel/segmentation_models.pytorch) library using TensorRT
But since firstly I need to convert torch model into ONNX format and I faced an issue I'm here

**Describe the bug**
onnxruntime gpu performance 5x worse than pytorch gpu performance and at the same time onnxruntime cpu performance 1.5x better than pytorch cpu performance 

**System information**
- OS Platform and Distribution (e.g., Linux Ubuntu 16.04): Ubuntu 18.04.5 LTS
- ONNX Runtime installed from: pip
- ONNX Runtime version: 1.7.0
- conda version: 4.9.2
- Python version: 3.7
- PyTorch version:  1.7.0 (py3.7_cuda11.0.221_cudnn8.0.3_0)
- GPU model and memory: 1080Ti 11Gb
- PyCharm CE version: 2021.1.2

**To Reproduce**
To test I have 2 conda environments (attached in [nn-speedup.txt](https://github.com/microsoft/onnxruntime/files/6721744/nn-speedup.txt) and [nn-speedup-cpu.txt](https://github.com/microsoft/onnxruntime/files/6721745/nn-speedup-cpu.txt))

I use the following code:

    # Settings
    device = torch.device("cuda:0")
    batch_size = 16
    batches_amount = 100
    print("Device", device)
    print("Batch size", batch_size)
    print("Batch amount", batches_amount)
    print()
    
    # Input
    x = torch.randn((batch_size, 3, 256, 256))
    x = x.to(device=device)
    x_np = to_numpy(x)
    
    # Model
    import segmentation_models_pytorch as smp
    model_torch = smp.Unet('efficientnet-b5', in_channels=3, classes=2, aux_params=None)
    model_torch.encoder.set_swish(memory_efficient=False)
    model_torch = model_torch.to(device=device)
    model_torch.eval()
    
    # Save torch outputs to compare them later with ort outputs
    with torch.no_grad():
        torch_outputs = model_torch(x)
    
    # Pass runs_amount batches through the torch model
    print("Running batches with pytorch")
    torch.cuda.synchronize()
    ts = time.perf_counter()
    for i in range(batches_amount):
        with torch.no_grad():
            _ = model_torch(x)
    torch.cuda.synchronize()
    te = time.perf_counter()
    elapsed_time = te - ts
    print("{:100} {:10.7f}".format(str(batches_amount) + " model_torch(x) took", elapsed_time))
    elapsed_time = elapsed_time / batches_amount
    print("{:100} {:10.7f}".format("avg" + str(batches_amount) + " model_torch(x) took", elapsed_time))
    print()
    
    # Export torch model to ONNX format
    print("Exporting torch model to ONNx format")
    model_onnx_path = os.path.join(".", "efficientnet-b5.onnx")
    torch.onnx.export(
        model_torch,  # model being run
        x,  # model input (or a tuple for multiple inputs)
        model_onnx_path,  # where to save the model (can be a file or file-like object)
        export_params=True,  # store the trained parameter weights inside the model file
        opset_version=12,  # the ONNX version to export the model to
        do_constant_folding=True,  # whether to execute constant folding for optimization
        input_names=['input'],  # the model's input names
        output_names=['output'],  # the model's output names
        dynamic_axes={
            'input': {0: 'batch_size'},  # variable length axes
            'output': {0: 'batch_size'}
        }
    )
    
    # Clear GPU memory
    print("Clearing GPU memory")
    del model_torch
    del _
    torch.cuda.empty_cache()
    
    # Import and check ONNX model
    print("Checking model from ONNX format")
    model_onnx = onnx.load(model_onnx_path)
    onnx.checker.check_model(model_onnx)
    
    # Create InferenceSession
    print("Creating InferenceSession")
    ort_session = onnxruntime.InferenceSession(model_onnx_path)
    print("onnxruntime.get_device()", onnxruntime.get_device())
    print()
    
    # Pass runs_amount batches through the ONNX model
    print("Running batches with onnxruntime")
    ts = time.perf_counter()
    for i in range(batches_amount):
        ort_inputs = {ort_session.get_inputs()[0].name: x_np}
        _ = ort_session.run(None, ort_inputs)
    te = time.perf_counter()
    elapsed_time = te - ts
    print("{:100} {:10.7f}".format(str(batches_amount) + " ort_session.run took", elapsed_time))
    elapsed_time = elapsed_time / batches_amount
    print("{:100} {:10.7f}".format("avg" + str(batches_amount) + " ort_session.run took", elapsed_time))
    print()
    
    # Compare ONNX Runtime and PyTorch results
    ort_inputs = {ort_session.get_inputs()[0].name: x_np}
    ort_outputs = ort_session.run(None, ort_inputs)[0]
    
    print("mean abs diff =", np.mean(np.abs(to_numpy(torch_outputs) - ort_outputs)))
    np.testing.assert_allclose(to_numpy(torch_outputs), ort_outputs, rtol=1e-03, atol=1e-05)

**Results**
CPU results:

> Device cpu
> Batch size 16
> Batch amount 10
> 10 model_torch(x) took 51.9717799
> 10 ort_session.run took 19.4771159

GPU results:

> Device cuda:0
> Batch size 16
> Batch amount 100
> 100 model_torch(x) took 12.3399892
> 100 ort_session.run took 61.6554922

**Expected behavior**
I expect the ONNX model to be faster on GPU in a similar way like on CPU

**Screenshots**
Whole CPU output
![Whole CPU output](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/30793581/123554857-6a0eb080-d782-11eb-8b21-840a0ec37c60.png)


Whole GPU output
![Whole GPU output](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/30793581/123554862-7561dc00-d782-11eb-9a6e-e5ed4c95f8bd.png)


**Additional context**
I've also tried [that](https://pytorch.org/tutorials/advanced/super_resolution_with_onnxruntime.html) example from PyTorch documentation and got similar results
I'm not sure about the time measurement of ort_session.run method because I think it executed asynchronously ([similarly to PyTorch](https://discuss.pytorch.org/t/copy-tensor-from-cuda-to-cpu-is-too-slow/13056/10)) but I didn't find information about correct time measurement with onnxruntime.
I will also be glad if someone shares information on setting up libraries for using TensorRT (Making work a specific combination of [CUDA, cudnn](https://www.onnxruntime.ai/docs/reference/execution-providers/CUDA-ExecutionProvider.html#requirements), [onnx and onnxruntime](https://www.onnxruntime.ai/docs/resources/compatibility.html#onnx-opset-support) was a real hell)

If you need any additional information feel free to ask

body:
**Describe the bug**
I'm using ML.Net and ONNX to process object detection with a Yolo onnx model. It works fine on my M1 Macbook pro. But when I deploy it to linux, I get this error:

```
The type initializer for 'Microsoft.ML.OnnxRuntime.NativeMethods' threw an exception.
 ---> System.DllNotFoundException: Unable to load shared library 'onnxruntime' or one of its dependencies. In order to help diagnose loading problems, consider setting the LD_DEBUG environment variable: Error loading shared library libonnxruntime: No such file or directory
   at Microsoft.ML.OnnxRuntime.NativeMethods.OrtGetApiBase()
   at Microsoft.ML.OnnxRuntime.NativeMethods..cctor() in Microsoft.ML.OnnxRuntime.dll:token 0x600006e+0x1
```
